page.text: In Accordance with the Statutes of the State of Illinois and the Ordinances of the City of Highland Park, a
Regular Meeting of the Highland Park Plan Commission is scheduled to be held at the hour of 7:30 P.M.
on Tuesday, November 5, 2013 at the Highland Park City Hall, 1707 St. Johns Avenue, Highland Park,
Illinois, during which it is anticipated there will be a discussion of the following:
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Highland Park City Hall, 1707 St. Johns Avenue
A. Consideration of Staff-Drafted Findings of Fact that Recommend to the City Council the

text.b: Approval of a Proposed Conditional Use of a Sports Training Facility at 3570 Western

page.text: Avenue. The Plan Commission will review and modify as necessary, staff-drafted Findings of
Fact that recommend approval of a Special Use Permit to allow the Warehouse Gym & Boxing
Club to establish a Sports Training Facility at 3570 Western Ave., as heard in Public Hearing 13-
B. Pre-Application Discussion for a Proposed Amendment to the Planned Development of

text.b: Crossroads Shopping Center at 113-229 Skokie Valley Rd. to: Modify the Parking and Site
Plan; Construct a 1400 Sq. Ft. Building Addition; and, Grant an Exception to Section
150.408 to Allow the Use of Sale of Soft Drinks by Vending Machine Outside of a Building.

page.text: The Plan Commission will give guidance to applicant/owner, Federal Realty Investment Trust, as
represented by Attorney Hal Francke, on its proposal for an amendment to the Crossroads
Shopping Center Planned Development to allow a building addition, reconfiguration of the site
plan, new outdoor vending machine sales, and a change in land use that affects the requirement for
Posted at City Hall before 5:00 p.m. on November 1, 2013

text.b: MINUTES OF THE REGULAR MEETING OF
THE PLAN COMMISSION OF THE CITY OF HIGHLAND PARK, IL

page.text: Council Chambers, City Hall, 1707 St. John’s Avenue
At 7:30 PM Vice Chair Stolberg called the meeting to order and asked Director Fontane to call
Members Present: Bilotti, Glenner, Kaplan, Reinstein, Stolberg
Director Fontane took the roll and declared a quorum present.
Staff Present: Fontane, Sloan, Cross, Smith, West

text.b: A. Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission, October 1, 2013

page.text: Vice Chair Stolberg entertained a motion to approve the minutes of the Regular Meeting
of the Plan Commission held on October 1, 2013. A motion for approval was made by
Commissioner Bilotti and seconded by Commissioner Kaplan; Commissioner Kaplan
voted present. On a voice vote, the minutes were approved unanimously.

text.b: A. Public Hearing 13-10-SUP-004 for Consideration of an Application to Allow a
Conditional Use of a Sports Training Facility at 3570 Western Avenue.

page.text: Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Vice Chair Stolberg read the Public Hearing Statement into the Record to open the Public
Hearing and the members present introduced themselves. Director Fontane read into the
record that proof of publication was on file at the Community Development office.
Planner West made a presentation for the above item which reviewed the Special Use
process, background of the use and location, zoning district, and business operations
which included information about the boxing club membership, classes for children, site
configuration and on-site parking, plat of survey, use, special use standards and
The Commission did not have any immediate questions for staff and the Vice Chair
invited the public to speak on the matter. Counsel Burkland administered the oath.
Mr. Ken Chafey, 530 Old Elm Rd., Highland Park, was concerned about deliveries, trucks
leaving ruts in the parkway, increased traffic and debris.
Planner West stated there would be no large deliveries.
Mr. Albert Falcon, Highland Park, applicant, stated there are no large deliveries to his
business and there is large container in the back for garbage. He stated the only traffic
Commissioner Kaplan asked where the children would be waiting for their parents to pick
Mr. Falcon stated they would be waiting inside.
Commissioner Kaplan asked if there would be loitering outside.
Mr. Falcon stated there would be no loitering.
Commissioner Reinstein asked about the discrepancy in numbers regarding parking and
Planner West stated the numbers are based on the s.f. of the building for persons in
permitted occupancy for fire prevention permitting. Parking requirements are not based
Commissioner Reinstein asked what the parking should be for this use.
Planner West stated there is no defined amount. It is determined by the Zoning
Administrator based on the specific business.
Commissioner Kaplan asked about the maximum number of students at one time.
Mr. Falcon stated each trainer only has 2 students at a time.
Commissioner Kaplan stated this area had been discussed a few months ago regarding a
dance studio and did not see any large issues from this use.
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Vice Chair Stolberg requested a motion to close the public comment portion of the public
hearing. Commissioner Glenner so motioned which was seconded by Commissioner
Commissioner Kaplan motioned to direct staff to prepare findings of fact to approve the
application to establish a conditional use of a sports training facility at 3570 Western Ave.
The motion was seconded by Commissioner Bilotti.
On a voice vote, the motion passed unanimously.

text.b: 13-10-ZTA-004 for a Proposed Text Amendment to Chapter 150, Articles II
(Interpretations and Definitions), IV (Conditional and Permitted Uses), V (Planned
Developments), VII (Area, Bulk and Density), VIII (Off-Street Parking and Loading)
to establish a new Article XXIII (Downtown Form and Design) of City of Highland
Park Zoning Code of 1997 (as Amended); and,
13-08-REZ-002 for a Proposed Zoning Map Amendment to Properties Currently
Zoned RM1 Medium to High Density Multiple Family; RO Residential Office
District; and, B4 Service Business District.

page.text: Vice Chair Stolberg read the Public Hearing Statement into the Record to open the Public
Hearing and the members present introduced themselves. Director Fontane read into the
record that proof of publication was on file at the Community Development office.
Planner Smith made a presentation for the above items that included: the amendment
process, context of recommendations as they relate to the vision statement for downtown
Highland Park, strategic issues for redevelopment, Lakota Group team project study area,
identified redevelopment constraints, build-out renderings for the North Triangle and
Sunset Park, new zoning district concepts, current and proposed zoning text and map,
proposed increase in permitted building heights, building height definition for the RO, B4
and B5 zoning districts, historic and proposed building height restrictions, proposed off-
street parking amendments for RO, B4 and B5 zoning districts, proposed off-street
parking amendments multi-family residential, retail and service parking requirements,
planned development thresholds, new Article XXIII - Downtown Form and Design, future
connectivity and frontage classification map, downtown form guidelines, and street
Vice Chair Stolberg thanked Planner Smith for his presentation.
Commissioner Bilotti asked about the planned development recommendation from the
consultant and asked what the Community Development Dept. recommends.
Planner Smith stated it was not their place to evaluate the consultant’s, but that direction
depended on the approach the Commission wanted to take as a policy matter.
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Vice Chair Stolberg invited members of the audience who desired to speak on the matter
to rise for the oath. Counsel Burkland administered the oath.
Mr. Dan Wattick, 1660 First St., Highland Park, read a letter from the president of the
Sheridan Square Condo Association stating they were opposed to a change in the zoning.
Mr. Ron Lesky, 1660 First St., Highland Park, stated businesses on Laurel are on a natural
line of separation from Second St. He thought the area around his condo development
should stay the same so it would not affect the residential character.
Mr. Richard Goldstein, 1649 Hickory, Highland Park, referred to the B4-6 next to his
building and stated he objected to the change since his building is only three stories and he
was concerned if a developer were to build a five or six story building it would dwarf their
property and be an eyesore. He suggested making the area a B4-5.
Mr. Bill Dietrich, 1930 Dale, Highland Park, former Chair of the Plan Commission,
thanked Manager Sloan, Planner Smith and staff for their efforts in the study. He thought
the product produced by the Lakota group met the high expectations of the City. Their
objective was to develop regulations that promote the City’s vision statement and
reinvestment in the downtown. The comprehensive map and text amendment proposals
are the results of this effort. In the process one of his concerns was parking. Lending
institutions are very concerned about this and are a constraint on how much parking a
developer will provide. Tenants are a second constraint and the last thing they want is not
enough parking. He thought that what was proposed is a good way to balance between the
overly prescriptive parking requirements and recognizes in the marketplace the City does
have allies who want to achieve the same results the City wants.
Mr. Hal Emalfarb, 100 Laurel, Highland Park, was excited about the process of
revitalizing the community and hoped they would deliberate this issue carefully.
Mr. Rob Rowe, 858 Baldwin, Highland Park, representative for the owner of the 76
Station at Central and McGovern. The owner has acquired other property in the area and
they are currently in discussions with developers. They are looking at apartments. He
stated there is a shortage of smaller units in Highland Park and a number of people are
moving out of their houses and want smaller units. He stated he supported the study.
Ms. Mag Sibbernsen, 574 Vine, Highland Park, asked about the economic impact on the
small housing units and would there be a decrease in value. If so, what provisions is the
Mr. Lawrence Levin, 2021 St. John’s, Highland Park, stated there are a lot of children
who walk along Elm Pl. and Sheridan Rd. and any zoning which would affect the traffic in
that area would be detrimental to them. He asked the Plan Commission to consider this.
Ms. Ann Israel, 2021 St. John’s, Highland Park asked about density and the 800 s.f.
apartment size. She asked who would live in an apartment of that size. She asked if there
had been cost analyses of the infrastructure changes involved.
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Director Fontane stated they had received a letter from Lawrence Hillman regarding this
matter which was entered into the record.
Vice Chair Stolberg asked for a motion to close the public comment portion of the public
hearing. Commissioner Bilotti so moved; the motion was seconded by Commissioner
Vice Chair Stolberg thanked the public for their input.
Commissioner Reinstein asked about the different B4 categories and if the zoning
classification would apply to residential, retail and office.
Planner Smith replied the B4 is a mixed zoning district and allows commercial, office and
residential above the first floor. There is no proposal to change what can be built in the
B4. The difference of the B4-4, B4-5, and B4-6 relates to the intensity of development
Commissioner Reinstein asked what the ground floor would be.
Planner Smith replied non-residential. It could be office, service or retail.
Commissioner Reinstein asked about the second floor and up.
Planner Smith replied it could be office or residential.
Commissioner Reinstein asked if could be a six-story office building.
Planner Smith replied it depends upon the district. He stated there is no requirement that
Commissioner Reinstein asked if there is a project which meets the minimum size and it is
all office, would a parking deck count as a story.
Planner Smith stated if it was underneath, it would not. If it was decked above ground it
Commissioner Reinstein stated the Lakota study handled parking by putting it
underground. He asked if that was the look they want should the code address it.
Planner Smith stated the code does address it. While the code does not require
underground parking, some of the items in proposed Article XXIII indentify where
Manager Sloan stated if you look at the drawings and the study they made assumptions
about some parking being indoors and some surface parking. This is described in the new
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Planner Smith stated a vehicular frontage street provides for increased setbacks from the
street and a limited area for surface parking. One concept is not to have a field of parking
Commissioner Reinstein asked about more density for sites with multiple uses, daytime
traffic and residents. He wanted to know how the zoning code would change if there was
Planner Smith stated the increases are predominantly about residential.
Commissioner Reinstein stated he favored granting higher heights and more density for
residential only. He did not want to establish Highland Park as the center for the north
shore office market. He asked what the zoning code would look like to prevent this.
Manager Sloan stated they had to change the proposed policies so they do not end up with
Planner Smith asked if Commissioner Reinstein’s vision for the areas out of the core was
multi-story residential. He stated one of theories behind form based codes is the design
character of the buildings within broad parameters.
Manager Sloan stated if asked, the land use policy for any given building could be
adjusted, they could do that, but not doing it leaves it open to the market.
Commissioner Reinstein asked if you were a developer and wanted to forego the ground
floor commercial space, would that be possible.
Planner Smith stated B4 does not allow for ground floor residential space. He stated you
might find the management office on the ground floor. If you desire strictly residential the
Commissioner Glenner asked how they should address the transition areas.
Manager Sloan asked if he meant along Central where the B4-6 was recommended.
Planner Smith stated the zoning map Lakota recommended is not sacrosanct.
Vice Chair Stolberg stated these were not unique questions – height, traffic, parking, and
asked if the City had commissioned a traffic study.
Planner Smith stated a traffic study was not performed.
Vice Chair Stolberg asked about parking and people saying it is tight. He thought this
referred to street parking. However, Renaissance Place and Port Clinton report under
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Planner Smith stated Renaissance Place is not fully occupied and if it was there would be
a higher percentage of use. During the peak hours there is presently readily available
Vice Chair Stolberg mentioned the new zoning B4, B5 and B6 and new method of
calculating height rather than to the middle of the peak. He asked where the height is
calculated at 50’ it is feasible that the peak is 59’. He stated this space would not be
Vice Chair Stolberg mentioned Laurel Ave. and the possibility of changing the western
portion from B4-6 to B4-5. He asked if the maximum height in the district was 50’.
Planner Smith stated they have raised it from three-stories and 40’ to four-stories and 50’
Vice Chair Stolberg asked if a permissible use in the B4-6, would be four-stories, 50’.
Planner Smith stated they would not regulate the height in terms of feet in this district.
Commissioner Glenner asked what other commissions were involved at this point.
Planner Smith replied it was just the Plan Commission now.
Commissioner Glenner asked if they had talked to police and fire departments.
Vice Chair Stolberg requested a motion to continue the hearing to December 3, 2013. A
motion to continue the hearing to December 3
, at 7:30pm in the Council Chambers was
made by Commissioner Reinstein and seconded by Commissioner Glenner. On a voice
vote the motion passed 4-1. Commissioner Bilotti voted no.

text.b: C. Preapplication Discussion for a Proposed Planned Development of Mixed-Use Retail
and Multi-Family Residential Building at 515-555 Roger Williams Ave.; and,
Proposed Zoning Code Text Amendments to Modify the Area, Bulk and Density
Requirements for the B2 Ravinia Commercial District and B2-RW Roger Williams

page.text: Planner Cross made a presentation for the above item including summary information,
proposed mixed-use building and site plan, PUD relief vs. code text amendments,
proposed parking, issues for consideration, parking recommendations, shared public
parking, building height and density, district build-out scenarios, master plan consistency,
Commissioner Bilotti asked if these units would be rental.
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Planner Cross replied they would be rental.
Commissioner Kaplan asked about the existing parking lot north of the property along the
tracks and wanted to know if the entrance would be one way and exit on Pleasant.
Planner Cross stated this would be the most likely traffic pattern.
Commissioner Reinstein asked if commercial traffic would enter there also.
Planner Cross replied it would and the parking immediately behind the proposed building
is committed to residential. Some of the other parking on the shared property would be
Commissioner Reinstein asked if someone went shopping they would not park on site but
Manager Sloan stated there is a pass through in the design so you can walk from the back
of the building to the front.
Commissioner Reinstein asked if commercial and stores owners would park in the rear.
Manager Sloan confirmed this and would pass through the building.
Planner Cross stated the parking restricted to residential use is behind the building.
Commissioner Kaplan asked about the number of parking spaces and the number of
complementary spaces and stated that as each property along the block is developed there
are fewer common parking spaces for future developments. He asked at what it point does
this development get more than its fair share of the common parking spaces.
Planner Cross stated the density of developments would play a role. If only 10,000-
15,000 s.f. of land can be assembled the density would not be as great as if the Walgreen’s
site were redeveloped. As each proposal is considered they would require a vacancy study
Manager Sloan stated it depends on each site. This street is front and center in its ability
to have a reduction of vehicles based on its proximity to the train. It is possible there may
be less than one car per residential unit. The shared complementary use would have to be
Commissioner Bilotti asked about the number of parking spaces available within 400’.
Commissioner Reinstein thought that was a sizeable amount and asked how they are being
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Manager Sloan stated they would present that information at public hearing and the
application and would have to supply a parking study showing vacancy rates.
Commissioner Reinstein asked what would happen during the Ravinia season.
Manager Sloan stated Ravinia has moved its shuttle parking to different places over the
years and that would be something to consider with more redevelopment.
Commissioner Glenner asked if the applicant had compelling reasons to go forward.
Manager Sloan stated they asked the City Council to look at it and asked staff to make
recommendations in regards to the feasibility of policy change. They would collectively
work on this with the applicant.
Commissioner Glenner asked about the hidden parking to the north and how much it is
Manager Sloan stated every time she had been there no one was using it. At one time
Ravinia Plumbing filled the spaces with their vans but since they have left it is usually
Commissioner Glenner stated the shared parking made sense and thought they should be
exploring it. He would like to see something happen at this site.
Commissioner Reinstein asked about the building height and if the Ravinia advisory group
Manager Sloan stated they encouraged the applicant to give them the best architectural
result and they wanted the Commission to see what this would look like. They could
compare it to the building across the street which was built to meet current code and think
about which form is the desired going forward.
Vice Chair Stolberg agreed this meeting should be done so as not to slow the applicant
down and would be in favor of a policy change rather than specific relief. In terms of the
height, this is probably the best corner for a higher building and it would not be offensive
to the block. He asked about the mechanicals on roof. He asked if they had done
anything similar relating to shared parking; and, that if the applicant is seeking parking
relief, what would be the public benefit in exchange. He thought maybe the City could
defray some of the maintenance costs and save the developer the cost of building parking
spaces. Maybe there could be some annual contribution to maintenance of the shared
Manager Sloan stated this was a PUD regardless of policy change and any relief would
include the discussion of a public benefit.
Commissioner Reinstein mentioned the location of the site and the height and asked if
they proposed to zone the rest of the block at different height.
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Manager Sloan stated part of the policy discussion would be to set a height. They would
find the right height for the entire block and see if this particular project would still needed
Vice Chair Stolberg asked if the current permissible height is 35’. Manager Sloan
Mr. Alfred Klairmont, applicant, 2233 Egandale Rd., Highland Park, made a presentation
for the above item and asked for the Commission’s guidance.
Commissioner Bilotti asked if there would be street parking in front.
Manager Sloan stated there would be and they would be closing one of the driveways.
Commissioner Reinstein asked about the unit sizes compared to the building the east side
Mr. Klairmont stated there would be eight units on each floor, two-bedroom, two-bath.
There would two one-bedrooms on each floor. He stated they would be condo quality
Commissioner Reinstein asked who they expected to rent the units.
Mr. Klairmont stated they expected a transit oriented tenant. He stated the developer is
not asking for any financial assistance.
Commissioner Kaplan asked what the site included and if it included the insurance office
Mr. Mike De Rouin, Fitzgerald Assoc. Architects, 912 W. Lake St., Chicago, IL, stated
Commissioner Kaplan asked about the traffic pattern and if everyone enters from Roger
Commissioner Kaplan asked some if the residents might be concerned about this.
Mr. Klairmont stated he thought they would be excited about an improved Ravinia district.
Commissioner Kaplan stated it was something to take into account.
Vice Chair Stolberg stated the traffic would not be what it used to be. They would await
the results of the traffic study. He thought the target market were tenants who would take
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Manager Sloan mentioned the affordable housing north of the alley and their only means
of ingress and egress was through the alley. So there is already regular residential traffic.
Commissioner Kaplan asked about the six units of affordable housing.
Manager Sloan stated they are required to have an affordable housing component.
Commissioner Kaplan asked if these would be the one-bedroom units.
Manager Sloan replied they have to be in proportion to the number of market rate units
and there would be some two-bedrooms and some one-bedrooms.
Commissioner Reinstein asked about the area in the back for proposed paved parking –
quantity to be determined. He stated it was almost like a ravine.
Mr. Joe Villanti, Imperial Realty, stated he had walked it off and it was about 125’ where
they could put parking closest to the east.
Commissioner Reinstein stated it did not look like there was 10’ from the north edge of
the alley into the brush without dropping down 3’.
Mr. Valenti stated it lined up with the parking farther to the west.
Councilman Blumberg asked the applicant for renderings that showed the building in
Commissioner Glenner asked what direction they should give staff.
Manager Sloan stated that if there was support for a scenario for a policy change and that
Councilman Blumberg stated he thought that if this proposal was discussed at a Ravinia
association meeting. He thought they would have someone here to comment on it.
Mr. Klairmont stated he had presented this to the Ravinia Neighbors board members but
Commissioner Reinstein asked if they had any comments on the height of the building.
Mr. Klairmont stated it was a positive meeting with a small group.
Manager Sloan stated the meeting schedule was the regular schedule with one exception
in April with back to back meetings on the first and second Tuesdays.
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission
Manager Sloan stated they could have an early quorum call for that date.
Commissioner Reinstein motioned to recommend adoption of the 2014 meeting schedule
to City Council; the motion was seconded by Commissioner Kaplan. On a voice vote,
Manager Sloan stated that there was no briefing.
Vice Chair Stolberg entertained a motion to adjourn. Commissioner Bilotti so motioned,
which was seconded by Commissioner Kaplan. On a voice vote, the motion passed
The Plan Commission adjourned at 10:45 PM.
Regular Meeting of the Plan Commission

text.b: Consideration of Staff-Drafted Findings of Fact that Recommend to the City
Council the Approval of a Proposed Conditional Use of a Sports Training Facility at
3570 Western Avenue as heard in Public Hearing #13-10-SUP-004

page.text: Project Description: The owners and operators of the Highland Park business, the Warehouse Gym &
Boxing Club, have relocated from 1660 Old Skokie Valley Road to the subject
property. The business will serve approximately 50 adult members, groups of
children, and children with special needs during pre-scheduled business hours.
The Applicants will be making no changes to the existing site plan; interior
alterations have been completed to convert the building from a retail hardware
store into a sports training school and gymnasium.
1) Public Hearing for a Special Use Permit
2) Forward recommendation as Finding of Fact to City Council
• At the October 15, 2013 Plan Commission meeting the above referenced public hearing was
opened and staff presented a proposal to establish a Conditional Use of a Sports Training Facility
on the Subject Property at 3570 Western Avenue. Following public testimony and Commission
discussion, the Commission voted (5-0) to direct staff to draft findings of fact recommending
approval for Commission’s consideration at the next scheduled hearing.
k:\plan commission 2013\13-10-sup-004 3570 western\11-5-2013 plan commission\11-05-2013 rfpca 3570 western ave -
• In August of 2013, the Applicants, the owners of the Warehouse Gym & Boxing Club, applied
for a Letter of Intent to occupy the space at 3570 Western Avenue to relocate their business from
1660 Old Skokie Valley Road. On August 20, 2013 the Building Division replied to the
Applicants with a letter stating that they were in compliance with all building codes, however, the
use proposed (active at the time of application) was a Conditional Use within the B1 zoning
district and in violation for operating without this approval. The applicants were issued a
Conditional Occupancy which expires in December 1, 2013. By this time, the operator of the
business must complete the Conditional Use review process.
The Warehouse Gym & Boxing Club is considered a “Sports Training School.” The Zoning Code
defines a sports training school as follows:
SPORTS TRAINING SCHOOL: A facility designed principally for the commercial indoor
instruction of athletic activities and skills involved in the performance of team and individual
sports, including, without limitation, archery, boxing, cycling, golf, martial arts, running,
swimming, and tennis. “Sports Training School” does not include facilities that provide
instruction in, or that offer the opportunity to train in, engage in, or practice, in any manner and
for any purpose, the firing or discharge of any firearm. (Ord. 78-13, J. 30, p. 232-237, passed
The Department of Community Development recommends that the Plan Commission review the Staff
Drafted Findings of Fact in relation to the request to establish a Special Use Permit for a Sports Training
Facility on the Subject Property at 3570 Western Avenue.
k:\plan commission 2013\13-10-sup-004 3570 western\11-5-2013 plan commission\3570 western ave -

text.b: Warehouse Gym & Boxing Club - 3570 Western Avenue

page.text: At a public hearing of the City of Highland Park Plan Commission on October 15
Commission voted (5-0) to support the request from the applicants, Albert & Lucy Falcon,
Owners & Operator of Warehouse Gym & Boxing Club, to Establish a Conditional Use of a
Sports Training School on the Subject Property at 3570 Western Avenue and directed staff to
draft Findings of Fact that recommend approval of the request.
The Plan Commission or the City Council, as the case may be, shall not recommend or grant a
special use permit be issued unless it shall make findings of fact based upon evidence presented
at the hearing in any given case that:
(1) The special use will serve the public convenience at the location of the subject property;
or the establishment, maintenance, or operation of the special use will not be detrimental
to or endanger the public health, safety, morals, comfort, or general welfare;
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the operation of a Sports Training School is
compatible with the zoning district in which it is located and the surrounding land uses
and therefore will not be detrimental to or endanger public health, safety, morals,
comfort, or general welfare, and will serve the public convenience at the location of the
(2) The location and size of the special use, the nature and intensity of the operation involved
in or conducted in connection with the special use, the size of the subject property in
relation to such special use, and the location of the site with respect to streets giving
access to it, shall be such that it will be in harmony with the appropriate, orderly
development of the zoning district in which it is located;
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the proposed Conditional Use is appropriate
for the location in terms of the nature and intensity of the operation, the size of the
subject property in relation to a Sports Training School serving 50 adults and children,
and the existing site access and parking. The existing building with 12 parking spaces is
in harmony with the development of the B1- Neighborhood Commercial zoning district
(3) That the special use will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other property in
the immediate vicinity of the subject property for the purposes already permitted in such
zoning district, nor substantially diminish and impair the value of other property in the
k:\plan commission 2013\13-10-sup-004 3570 western\11-5-2013 plan commission\3570 western ave -
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the proposed Conditional Use that is to be
located in an existing building will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other
property in the immediate vicinity of the subject property for the purposes already
permitted in such zoning district, nor substantially diminishes or impairs the value of
(4) The nature, location, and size of the buildings or structures involved with the
establishment of the special use will not impede, substantially hinder, or discourage the
development and use of adjacent land and buildings in accord with the regulations of the
zoning district within which they are located;
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the reuse of the existing building for the
proposed Conditional Use will not impede, substantially hinder, or discourage the
development and use of adjacent land and buildings.
(5) Adequate utilities, access roads, drainage, and other necessary facilities have been or will
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that adequate utilities, access roads, drainage, and
other necessary facilities have been provided to existing building, and will continue to
serve the proposed Conditional Use with no necessary increase in capacity.
(6) Parking areas of adequate size for the special use shall be properly located and suitably
screened from adjoining residential uses, and the entrance and exit driveways to and from
these parking areas shall be designed to prevent traffic hazards, eliminate nuisance, and
minimize traffic congestion in the public streets;
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the parking areas are of adequate size for the
Conditional Use and its operation with the number of employees and customers as
indicated in the application for Conditional/Special Use; and, is properly located and
suitably screened from adjoining residential uses.
(7) The special use shall in all other respects conform to the applicable regulations of the
zoning district in which it is located, except as such regulations may, in each instance, be
modified as provided in this Chapter;
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the proposed Conditional Use in all other
respects conforms to the applicable regulations of the zoning district in which it is
(8) There is reasonable assurance that the special use will be completed and maintained as
k:\plan commission 2013\13-10-sup-004 3570 western\11-5-2013 plan commission\3570 western ave -
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the proposed Conditional Use reasonable
assurance that the special use will be completed and maintained as and if authorized.
(9) The special use shall comply with all applicable requirements set forth in this Chapter.
Finding: The Plan Commission finds that the proposed Conditional Use complies with
all applicable requirements set forth in this Chapter
The application for a the Conditional Use of a ‘Sports Training School’ known as the Warehouse
Gym and Boxing Club at 4570 Western Avenue meets all of the relevant standards above and
will not a be a detriment to the surrounding community; no additional conditions are
recommended for this proposed use. The Plan Commission supports approval this application
and forwards the above recommendation to the City Council.
Pre-Application Discussion of Proposed Amendments to the Planned
Development for Crossroads Shopping Center to: Modify the Parking and
Site Plan, Construct a 1400 Sq. Ft. Building Addition, and Grant an Exception
to Section 150.408 to Allow the Use of Sale of Soft Drinks by Vending
Crossroads Shopping Center, 113-229 Skokie Valley Road
Federal Realty, owners of the Crossroads Shopping Center, are
proposing to reconfigure the parking and site plan to add 11parking
spaces, add a 1,400 square foot building addition , and install two
Process Required: 1) Article V, Section 150.545 (2) - Amendment to an Approved
2) Review processes as required by the Article V Section 150.530-
Crossroads Shopping Center was developed as a Planned Development with a
development agreement specifying the nature of the commercial activity on the site, a
specific plan of development (site plan), and physical improvements on the property.
Substantial Changes to the Development as described in Chapter 150, Section 150.454
require the adoption of an amendatory ordinance after a public hearing is held in the
manner as required for a new planned development.
Federal Realty has identified a need to reconfigure the parking lot near the middle of the
shopping center. Currently there is an outdoor dining area in front of the Old Chicago
Smoke Shop, Mizrahi Grill, and Hoffman Jewelers. The revised plan will eliminate
much of that area and decrease the angle of the sharp curve in the drive aisle in front of
these businesses. The reconfiguration will also add approximately eleven new parking
Another change proposes a 1,400 square-foot addition to the shopping center. Plans
indicate that the addition will be on the front of the tenant space immediately south of
Party City. This change is part of a larger transformation to the north end of the center as
27,000 square feet of retail area is assembled for a grocery store use. This addition of
Floor Area will require modification of the façade and increase the floor area that is
counted in the determination of off-street required parking. The change in land use from
retail land uses to a grocery store use will also result in a higher off-street parking space
requirement than is presently required for the uses (various retail) that the grocery store
The final part of the applicant’s proposal is an amendment to the Planned Development to
allow two new outdoor soft drink vending machines. The machines constitute sales
outside of a building and will require relief from the City Code to remain at Crossroads
The Crossroads Planned Unit Development was last amended in 2009 when LA Fitness
moved into the center. A minor amendment was approved to both clarify the center’s
square footage (increase of 106 square feet) and establish a required parking quantity for
LA Fitness of 204 spaces (at peak hour) based on a plumbing code maximum capacity of
the facility of 618 persons. These changes met the standards for a Minor Amendment as
defined Article 5 of the Zoning Code. They were approved by the City Manager, ratified
by the City Council and did not require a public hearing process before the plan
A public hearing will be necessary to consider the Substantial Changes proposed for the
Crossroads Planned Unit Development. The Plan Commission is asked to provide
guidance to the applicant in the preparation of an application that will be considered at a
future public hearing. After the public hearing, the Plan Commission will make a
recommendation to the City Council upon making findings that the proposed
amendments satisfy the standards set forth in Article V Sections 150.520 and 150.1404.
The following is a summary of preliminary staff-identified issues that the Plan
The parking requirements for Crossroads Shopping Center were established in
Exhibit D2 in the 2009 PUD amendment related to LA Fitness. The exhibit is
The tenant spaces highlighted in Figure 1 represent the 27,000 square feet of area
proposed for conversion to a grocery store use. Ninety-one spaces in Crossroads’
parking supply are required for the land uses presently occupying the spaces
which are intended for future grocery store use.
The applicants have provided a traffic and parking study that analyzes the
anticipated impact of a 27,000-square foot grocery store and 7,000 square feet of
new restaurant use. The study also examined the current levels of use in the
Crossroads parking lot and measured vacancy and parking availability at peak
times (see Exhibits 5A and 5B in the study). The study concludes that the
existing parking capacity at the Shopping Center will be adequate for the
Grocery stores have a higher parking demand than general retail land uses. The
conversion of 27,000 square feet of retail uses to a grocery store use will trigger
an increase in the parking requirement at Crossroads of 20 spaces. The
conversion of 7,000 square feet of retail space to a restaurant use increases the
parking requirement by approximately 80 spaces. It’s worth noting that these
parking estimates do not exempt certain portions of the buildings that would not
count towards parking requirements, such as storage areas and restrooms.
Modifications to the site plan include the following:
• decreasing the common open space/ outdoor seating area in front of
Mizrahi Grill and the Smoke Shop
• reducing the sharp turn in the drive aisle in front of those stores
• adding a bump-out on the west property line to slow traffic in that drive
• converting the interior drive aisles from one-way angled parking to two-
The 90-degree parking stalls require a 25’8” drive aisle between them, which is
wider than the 20’ aisle required for the existing one-way angled parking. The
plan proposes 25’5” drive aisles. These are three inches narrower than required
The site plan identifies two areas set aside as “cart corrals” for the collection of
shopping carts in the parking lot. With the anticipated addition of the grocery
user, the cart corrals will be important, but occupy a total of four parking spaces.
Article 4 of the Zoning Code prohibits outdoor sales, but relief can be granted
through the PUD process. Relief for permanent outdoor sales areas, although the
areas were deemed “accessory sales” have been authorized through the planned
development process at Thornton’s Gas and similarly requested for Bucky’s gas
The use at Crossroads is not an accessory use, since the machines are not
associated with any occupying principal use, but through the Planned
Development Process relief may be granted for the requested two outdoor
vending machines. The relief can be granted by a specific square footage, as it
was for the gas stations, as well as for a specific number of vending machines.
Crossroads Shopping Center uses the private alleyway at the east edge of the
center’s property for garbage removal. Individual roll-off dumpsters serving each
of the tenants are kept behind the building. A new 27,000 square foot grocery
store may generate more refuse than the existing tenants, so the Commission may
wish to discuss how garbage removal will be facilitated for this specific use and
for refuse consolidation of multiple tenants. The nuisance characteristics
associated with refuse collection should be considered. These might include
management of perishable food refuse; recycling separation; container screening;
and traffic, delivery, and fire lane conflict.
Members of the Police and Fire Departments have reviewed Crossroads’ proposed
site plan and shared the following concerns:
• The seating area outside Mizrahi Grill has been reduced in size and is
closer to the drive aisle. If the intent is to continue outdoor dining in this
area, then some type of protection for the patrons should be installed
• Aisle widths and dimensions need to be added to verify adequate turning
radii for fire and emergency apparatus, especially in the winter if snow
isn’t plowed curb-to-curb in the drive aisle.
The revised site plan identifies a 1,400 square foot addition on the Crossroads
Shopping Center. There is no indication of the height of the addition, or whether
it is intended as an open-air addition or an enclosed structure. Its design and
intended use will be important for determining whether the addition will be
counted toward the parking requirement for the grocery store.
Exterior alterations to Crossroads will require approval from the Design Review
Commission. However, the applicants have indicated a preference for pursuing
Design Review approval after receiving zoning entitlement for the improvements
so as to maintain tenant confidentiality. Staff has requested that the applicant
provide enough information about the addition to allow the determination of
associated parking impacts and give the Plan Commission and City Council a
clear idea of the bulk and massing of the new structure. It is possible that Design
Review may be requested as a condition of the preliminary approval, instead of a
The Department of Community Development recommends that the Plan Commission
consider the pre-application submittal and give direction to the applicant for the
preparation of a public hearing application.
(GHA) has reviewed the potential traffic and parking impacts for the above
referenced project. Federal Realty Investment Trust (FRIT) is requesting an amendment for the existing Planned
Development at Crossroads Shopping Center which will permit an expansion of ±1,440 square feet which will assist
in locating an approximately 28,000 sq ft grocery store near the north end of the center. Furthermore, as part of the
Amendment process, FRIT is seeking the ability to convert approximately 7,000 square feet of current retail space
The following analysis flows from a review of the existing conditions through the proposed plan while highlighting
our approach, methodology, and findings, ultimately providing various recommendations for your consideration.
Briefly summarizing, the additional traffic generated by the proposed commercial development can be readily
accommodated by the existing area roadways.
Exhibits and Appendices referenced in the following text are conveniently located in the Technical Addendum at the

i.b: Site Location Map and Photo Inventory

page.text: Exhibit 1 provides a location map of the site vicinity and Exhibit 2 provides photo inventory of operations at the
 The subject site is located along the east side of Skokie Valley Road, north of Lake Cook Road and
adjacent to US 41 (Eden’s Expressway) in the City of Highland Park.
 US 41 is classified as a principal arterial along the site frontage under the jurisdiction of the Illinois
 Along the subject site, Skokie Valley Road is classified as a major collector under the jurisdiction of the City
 Skokie Valley Road provides two travel lanes in each direction with left turn lanes at all three site
driveways. The northern and center drive provide separate left and right turn lanes exiting the site, while
only a single exit lane exists at the southern most drive.
Exhibit 3 summarizes the existing Weekday Morning and Evening, as well as Saturday Peak Hour traffic
volumes in the site vicinity. Weekday (6-9 AM and 3-6 PM) and Saturday (11 AM – 1 PM) Peak Period counts
were conducted by GHA on Thursday, September 19
The observed Weekday Peak Hours occurred from 8:00 to 9:00 AM and 3:45 to 4:45 PM and the Saturday
Peak Hour occurred from 12:00 noon to 1:00 PM.
No unusual activities (e.g. emergency vehicle activity, roadway construction, etc) or inclement weather were
observed during our counts that would be expected to impact traffic volumes or travel patterns in the vicinity.
Summaries of the existing traffic counts can be found in Appendix I.
In addition to the traffic data collected at the access driveways, GHA conducted hourly parking occupancy
from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM and on Wednesday September 11
to 7:00 PM. The center was divided into three separate zones for the purpose of our data collection. (See
Exhibits 5A&B tabulate the results from the Saturday and Wednesday parking counts, respectively. As can be
seen, each hour and Zone is color coded to help illustrate the current utilization of parking.
Saturday observations identify that Zones 1 and 2 experienced some time periods that have an occupancy of
61-85%, with only four hours having an overall occupancy of 61-85%. During the 3:00 PM hour, the nine
handicap spaces in Zone 1 were 100% occupied. Otherwise, each hour and Zone was less than 61% occupied
Weekday observations again illustrate that Zones 1 and 2 experienced some hours where parking was 61-85%
occupied, with only three hours having an overall occupancy of 61-85%. In Zone 3, during the 2:00 PM and
5:00 PM hours both handicap spaces were occupied.
Overall, it seems that there is a more than adequate parking supply for the current tenants of the building.
Appendix II provides the Preliminary Site Plan for the Crossroads Shopping Center. As previously noted, FRIT
proposes a small (±1,440 sq ft) addition near the north end of the center and anticipates occupying the
reconfigured space with an approximately 28,000 sq ft grocery tenant. Furthermore, modifications to the Zone 2
parking lot and circulation aisles are planned, which will result in a slight increase in parking supply.
While not illustrated on the plan, the proposed Amendment is also requesting the ability to replace
approximately 7,000 sq ft of “dry” retail spaces with additional restaurant space.
Exhibit 6 – Part A tabulates the anticipated traffic generations for the proposed development amendment based
on trip rate data published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) in the most recent, 9
the manual Trip Generation. Utilizing the Supermarket (Land Use #850) and High-Turnover (Sit-down)
Restaurant (LU #932) for the proposed grocer and infill restaurant space, the development is expected to
generate approximately 170 trips (combined entering and exiting), 375 trips, and 530 trips during the Weekday
Morning, Evening, and Saturday Peak Hours, respectively. Note that traffic generated by the existing uses has
not been removed from our September counts. As such, we believe that we have made an effort to analyze the
maximum traffic impacts of the proposed grocer and future restaurant space.
Exhibit 6 – Part B provides the anticipated trip distribution for the additional traffic, which is primarily based on
the existing traffic volumes and patterns observed by the existing Crossroads Shopping Center patrons. As can
be seen, it is anticipated that a slightly higher percentage of traffic will arrive from the south, but will depart to
the north and south more equally. Ultimately, trip distribution will be a function of a variety of factors, including
competing and complementary shopping / dining opportunities, access system and efficiency, as well as
ultimately where patrons and employees live.
Exhibit 7 illustrates the anticipated site traffic volumes generated by the proposed grocery store and restaurant
spaces which have been assigned to the area roadway network based on the project’s traffic characteristics as
discussed above and summarized in Exhibit 6 (i.e. traffic generations and trip distribution) and the site access
Site traffic and Existing traffic (see Exhibits 7 and 3) were combined to produce the Total Traffic, which is
Capacity Analyses were conducted at the intersections within the study area. The analysis parameters utilized
are listed in Part A, as published in the Transportation research Board’s (TRB) 2010 Highway Capacity Manual
(HCM). At signalized intersections, Level of Service (LOS) “reports” traffic operations using the letter
designations “A” (best) through “F” (worst) and measures the “control delay” per vehicle in seconds. LOS C is
often referred to as intersection “design” guideline and LOS D is usually considered as providing the lower
threshold of “acceptable” operations. LOS E and F are usually considered “unacceptable”.
At unsignalized intersections, the HCM methodology reports the results differently for Two-Way Stop Controlled
(TWSC) or All-Way Stop Controlled (AWSC) intersections. For TWSC intersections, LOS is reported for
conflicting movements on the major street (i.e. left turns onto the minor approach) and for each movement on
the stopped approach. Approach “control delay” is also reported in seconds per vehicle. Results of AWSC
analyses are slightly different. LOS is reported for each stopped approach as well as an average overall
intersection “control delay” in seconds per vehicle. LOS C and D continue to be considered “design” and
Exhibit 9 Part B. summarizes the intersection capacity analysis results for the Weekday Morning, Evening, and
Saturday Midday Peak Hours. As can be seen, the additional traffic generated by the grocery store and
restaurant developments will result in increased delays for vehicles exiting the center, primarily the additional
left turns. However, the majority of individual movements and overall approach operations will continue to
operate at or above the acceptable range. The Saturday Peak Hour is expected to be impacted the most,
particularly the center and south drives which will experience longer than desirable delays.
Even though the calculated delays for traffic exiting the shopping center are considered “unacceptable”, this
level of delay is common at TWSC intersections on a four lane roadways. Vehicles wishing to make a left hand
turn out of the driveways have to wait longer to find an available gap in both northbound and southbound traffic.
As the through volumes increase, the amount of available gaps decreases, thus causing the vehicle to wait
Both the north and center drive will provide separate right and left or left-through lanes for exiting traffic. This
configuration allows right turning vehicles to enter traffic without being delayed by those waiting to make left
turns. The anticipated queues (or stacking) of vehicles for those movements expected to operate at LOS E or F
was calculated and provided in Exhibit 9. As can be seen, the weekday queues can generally be
accommodated without issues, some of the longer queues on Saturday afternoons have potential to extend into
The Highway Capacity Software (HCS) summary printouts are provided as Appendix III for reference.
Exhibit 10 schematically illustrates the traffic recommendations to accommodate the additional traffic associated
with the grocery store and restaurant addition. Key components include:
 The center drive should be striped to provide a separate left and right turn lane
 The parking lot should be reconfigured as shown in the site plan (see Appendix II) to provide additional
parking spaces and a more efficient layout for traffic.
A shared parking analysis was completed for the existing operations with the addition of the restaurant and
Under the City’s Zoning Ordinance different sizes and types of retail uses require different parking standards.
The proposed grocery store and restaurant use have higher requirements (4.0 and 15.0 spaces per 1,000
square feet, respectively) than the current retail tenant requirement of 3.3 spaces per 1,000 square feet.
As previously noted and discussed, GHA conducted hourly parking occupancy counts at the Shopping Center
on both a Weekday and a Saturday. Exhibit 11 provides the shared parking calculations for the proposed
As planned, including a 1,440 sq ft addition, a grocery user is proposed to occupy approximately 28,000 square
feet of space. Using the requirement of the Zoning Ordinance, 111 spaces would be required, a net increase of
almost 20 spaces over the current parking requirements. Similarly, converting approximately 7,000 sq ft of retail
space (using a 3.3 parking spaces / 1,000 sq ft requirement) to restaurant use (using a 15 parking space per
1,000 sq ft requirement) would require an additional 79 spaces. The current parking supply at Crossroads
cannot be expanded to meet this requirement. However, the City accepts the concept of shared parking,
acknowledging that not all uses experience their peak demand at the same time of the day.
Using hourly distribution of parking demands for the proposed uses and estimating the split of City required
spaces for the uses into employee and customer requirements based on data published by the ENO
Foundation for parking, GHA generated hourly parking demands for the proposed grocer and restaurant use.
As can be seen, the grocery use is expected to have a demand of 112 spaces during the 6:00 pm hour on a
weekday and the restaurant uses are expected to have a demand of 96 spaces at that 6:00 pm hour. When
these “new” demands are considered with the observed demand at 6:00 pm of 457 spaces, we can see that
there are expected to be 34 vacant spaces left in the center. If one considers the previously approved land
banked spaces north of the Chase Bank site, 75 vacant spaces would remain available.
The same calculation for the observed Saturday Peak of 11:00 am results in 29 and 70 spaces, respectively
The proposed parking supply of 699 spaces (not including the land banked spaces) is sufficient for the
proposed tenant mix for a variety of reasons, including:
 We have not removed the current tenant parking demands from our observed peaks
 The parking calculations are based on Gross Floor Area without the discounts for storage or stock space,
restrooms and mechanical space, and kitchen spaces as permitted in the City’s definition of GROSS
FLOOR AREA in Section 150.202 of the Zoning Ordinance
 Both ITE and ENO foundation would suggest lower parking demands for both grocery and restaurant uses
 While the center is currently approximately 94% leased, the peak observed demand of 462 spaces is less
than 75% of the parking currently required by Ordinance for the center.
Detailed hourly parking demand calculations are attached in tables 4.1 and 4.2 found in Appendix IV.
Based on our observations and analyses we feel that while delays will increase beyond the current situation at the
center and south driveway, the existing roadway network can accommodate the additional traffic generated by the
addition of the grocery store and future restaurant tenants to the Crossroads Shopping Center. Furthermore, based
on our shared parking analysis, it is our finding that the proposed parking supply is more than sufficient to meet the
demand associated with the proposed grocery store and restaurant additions.
The following Exhibits were previously referenced. They provide technical support for our observations, findings,
and recommendations discussed in the text.
III. Highway Capacity Software Summary Worksheets
